Award.AwardTitle: Development of an Integrated Serial Grinder and Photo-Imager for 3D Fossil Reconstruction
Award.AbstractNarration:
1028768
Maloof

This grant supports a two-year project to develop an automated serial grinder and image analysis system capable of rapid and high resolution 3-D imaging of small (cm scale) calcareous fossils imbedded within carbonate facies. Given the lack of suitable density contrast in such fossiliferous rocks, x-ray computed tomography will not work, neither will dissolution or disaggregation techniques, and standard manual serial sectioning polishing and subsequent photographing to ultimately build a 3-D image of the fossil morphology is extremely time consuming and greatly limits progress in studying such fossil remains. The PIs recent research has focused on manual examination of Neoproterozoic fossils which appear to be sponges found in stromatolitic facies of the Flinders Range of southeastern Australia and which appear to have survived throughout the so-called Snowball Earth time period where isotopic evidence from contemporaneous rocks suggest a global glaciation. A major outstanding question is how such organisms might have persisted in such an environment. The availability of a rapid method for study of early life forms from the Neoproterozoic would shed light on this question and the system would also be useful for study of other early life forms where the fossil remains and the host matrix offers little to no density contrast.

The development involves mating an imaging system to a commercially available serial grinder and developing the machine code and imaging routines to allow for automated serial grinding and 3-D fossil image construction and visualization. The project will involve a postdoc at Princeton, the PI and a colleague from the Princeton computational sciences department with expertise in image analysis. The project will also include a partnership with a private firm, SITU Research, that specializes in digital design and manufacturing. They will be responsible for the development of the machine code to mate the grinder with the imaging system. Undergraduate students will be engaged in sample preparation work for machine testing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2010, we published Maloof et al., Possible animal-body fossils in pre-Marinoan limestones from South Australia, Nature Geoscience, 3, pp. 653-659.  This work used a manual grinder and flat bed scanner to acquire serial images through 3~cm of rock.  The rock was 650 million year old limestone containing an array of cm-scale calcite elements. We hypothesized that these elements were random two-dimensional slices through three-dimensional objects, and sought to develop 3D images of these objects. However, the calcite elements in the calcite matrix had a density contrast of <0.0001% and were not accessible to X-ray based imaging. Therefore, we used the color contrast to reconstruct the objects by autotracing each element in each 2D slice, and then interpolating groups of vertically stacked polygons into 3D surfaces.  The result was a proposal for the world's oldest animal fossil, a cm-scale sponge-grade organism with an internal water canal system.

The range of materials (from rocks to bones to building materials to batteries) having small density contrasts but significant color/texture contrasts seemed substantial enough to merit further work developing the procedures for serial grinding and imaging. However, the process of manual grinding and scanning was time-consuming (330 hours for 3 cm or rock) and imprecise (removing the sample from the grinder bed for imaging after each grind led to persistent registration errors and distortions). Therefore, we set out to automate the process of 3D reconstruction by serial grinding and imaging.  


With the support of this grant, we purchased an off-the-shelf Mitsui CNC grinder capable of 1 micron precision. We then designed, fabricated and installed two major integrated systems on the grinder.  First, a misting and wiping system (colloquially called the `car wash') prepares the surface of the object to be imaged.  After each pass under the grinding wheel, the sample surface is washed, blown dry, misted with mineral oil, and cleaned with pneumatic neoprene wipers prior to imaging.  All of these procedures are automated and programmable to optimize the surface preparation for samples with different hardness, porosity, and permeability.


Next, after the `car wash', the sample moves beneath the positive-pressure camera housing that is mounted directly to the vertical arm of the CNC grinder. In this way, the camera moves with the sample surface, always maintaining the same focus. The camera is an 80 MP Phase One digital back coupled to a choice of Schneider macro lenses with different field of views, all optimized for copy-stand work. Our most common setup so far creates a field of view of 6x6 cm and pixels 4.5 microns in size. 

Because the sample never is removed from the grinder bed, we avoid registration errors. Using five high-contrast landmarks, we tested machine precision by cycling through 250 grinder sequences and measuring the apparent motion of each landmark, showing that horizontal precision is better than the size of 4.5 micron pixels.
